source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk1
evidence_span: A material development project was initiated to develop a new zirconium alloy, outside the ASTM specifications for Zircaloy-2 and Zircaloy-4, with optimized hydriding and corrosion properties for both boiling water reactors and pressurized water reactors.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk1
evidence_span: A material development project was initiated to develop a new zirconium alloy, outside the ASTM specifications for Zircaloy-2 and Zircaloy-4, with optimized hydriding and corrosion properties for both boiling water reactors and pressurized water reactors.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk1
evidence_span: These alloys were long-term corrosion tested in autoclaves at 400°C in steam.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk1
evidence_span: Also, a 520°C/24 h steam test was carried out.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk1
evidence_span: From a literature search, it appeared that increasing nickel, iron and decreasing tin would improve corrosion performance
composition_raw: increasing nickel, iron and decreasing tin

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk1
evidence_span: and increasing silicon content and adding niobium would improve hydriding performance.
composition_raw: increasing silicon content and adding niobium

evidence_span: These materials were then tested for corrosion performance in 400 and 520°C steam.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk1
evidence_span: TWCA melted small ingots, approximately 2 x 8 in weight, by the induction-slag melting process.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk1
evidence_span: The ingots were pre-heated to about 1020°C for 20 min prior to forging.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk1
evidence_span: The materials were forged to a dimension of about 25 by 110 by 140 mm

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk1
evidence_span: At the dimension of 25 by 110 by 140 mm , the material was hot-rolled, beta-quenched, and subsequently three cold rolling steps with intermediate anneals followed.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk3
evidence_span: The second-phase particles found in the different materials were of three kinds: (1) $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } _ { 2 }$ (Ni,Fe) tetragonal type, (2) ${ \bf Z r ( C r , F e ) } _ { 2 }$ hexagonal type, and (3) Zr-Si.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk3
evidence_span: It is clear that the chromium-bearing particles are the smallest and that the silicides are the largest. The nickel-bearing particles have an intermediate size.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk3
evidence_span: It is strange that not even one nickel-bearing particle was found in the Ref. $\mathbf { z } _ { \mathbf { I } ^ { - 2 } }$ material with a nickel content of $0 . 0 4 \%$ .

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk3
evidence_span: Between 1 to 2.3 atom percent of niobium was detected in seven SPPs in the NiFeNb' alloy.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: the nickel content in the investigated alloys is ranging from 400 to 2400 ppm (Table 1)

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: adding nickel over 0.04% by weight did not further improve corrosion resistance

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: a significant reduction in corrosion rate by adding nickel beyond 0.05% by weight is obtained

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: some of the silicon has a preference to concentrate in the Zr₂(Ni,Fe) particles, about 1 to 2 atom percent

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: one third of the niobium additions is concentrated in the chromium-bearing SPPs, that is, 1 to 2.3% by weight

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: adding niobium decreases the SPP sizes, see Fig. 4

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: In Zr-2 base alloy with about 0.1% by weight niobium, about two thirds of the niobium seem to be in the matrix while one third is concentrated in the chromium-bearing SPPs

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: The niobium content in the Zr(Cr,Fe)₂ type SPP is about 1 to 2 atom percent

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: Additions of niobium appears to reduce the SPP size

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk5
evidence_span: Uniform oxide mainly consists of m-ZrO2 and a smaller fraction of t-ZrO2 with columnar grains and some amount of equiaxed crystallites.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk5
evidence_span: Nodular oxides show a high open porosity and the grain shape tends to the equiaxed type.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk5
evidence_span: A fine network of pores along grain boundaries was found in oxides grown in water containing lithium.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk5
evidence_span: An enrichment of lithium within such oxides could be found by glow discharge opticai spectroscopy (GD-OES) depth profiling.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk5
evidence_span: In all oxides, a compact, voidfree oxide layer was observed at the metal/oxide interface.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk5
evidence_span: Compressive stresses within the oxide layer measured by an x-ray diffraction technique were significantly higher compared to previously published values.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk5
evidence_span: Electrical potential measurements on oxide scales showed the influence of the intermetallic precipitates on the potential drop across the oxide.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk5
evidence_span: In long-time corrosion tests of Zircaloy with varying temperatures, memory effects caused by the cyclic formation of barrier layers could be observed.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_035_chunk5
evidence_span: It was concluded that the corrosion mechanism of zirconium-based alloys is a barrier-layer controlled process. The protective properties of this barrier layer determine the overall corrosion resistance of zirconium alloys.
